A **stone golem**, ', is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The stone golem is [thick-skinned](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned"), and is one of the stronger types of [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem").

A stone golem has a single claw attack, and possesses [stoning resistance](/wiki/Stoning_resistance "Stoning resistance") along with the [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") of all golems.

A [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") that is subjected to [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") while [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into any other golem will become a stone golem.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Generation

Randomly-generated stone golems are always created hostile. Stone golems are always generated with 60 [HP](/wiki/HP "HP").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Stone golems can generate as a result of [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") if there are enough [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper"), [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver"), [platinum](/wiki/Platinum "Platinum"), [gemstone](/wiki/Gemstone "Gemstone"), or [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") objects in a pile of items.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) Stoning any other type of golem will turn them into a stone golem.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

The second map for [Medusa's Island](/wiki/Medusa%27s_Island "Medusa's Island") generates four stone golems just outside of [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa")'s room at level creation.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) Four stone golems are generated on the [Plane of Earth](/wiki/Plane_of_Earth "Plane of Earth") at level creation, and two are generated on the [Plane of Fire](/wiki/Plane_of_Fire "Plane of Fire") at level creation.

Stone golems leave behind a [statue](/wiki/Statue "Statue") of themselves containing their inventory upon death [instead of a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) They are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit a1b76593](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/a1b765936f807729e1c2cf3c7a9b928e34a277f5), stone golems generate with 100 HP.

## Strategy

Stone golems have a fairly powerful attack and slightly more AC than most golems, but they move half as fast as an unburdened player and lack most resistances outside of the usual ones for golems, so they should not be too difficult to defeat.

Casting [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") on a stone golem will turn it into a [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem"): while this makes it faster and more resistant, as well as giving it more damaging attacks, the flesh golem also has worse AC and base HP. Heroes that encounter stone golems through normal generation are usually well-equipped to handle flesh golems, and can use the spell to try and gain certain [intrinsics](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic") from the corpses - this also applies to the statues that stone golems leave behind upon being 'destroyed'.

Remember that statues left over from killing stone golems will not contain any items like randomly generated statues, minus whatever inventory the stone golem already possessed (which only occurs if they were polymorphed from another monster); randomly-generated statues of stone golems in the dungeon may still contain [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") as normal.

## History

The stone golem first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

From NetHack 3.0.0 to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on those versions, a hero in stone golem form that casts stone to flesh at themselves while [wielding](/wiki/Wielding "Wielding") a [footrice](/wiki/Footrice "Footrice") corpse without [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves") will become a [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem") as expected, but will not be affected by the wielded corpse - this is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") via [commit b99f8a0e](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/b99f8a0ebb5f3ef958133b2b1a2f75a01726caf8) so that the hero will immediately become a stone golem again in this case.

Additionally, casting stone to flesh at a statue or [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of a stone golem produces a single [meatball](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball"), since any golem other than the flesh or [leather golem](/wiki/Leather_golem "Leather golem") is considered "[vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian")" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in NetHack 3.6.0 via [commit 30d81e90](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/30d81e909793081790b0aa1d127c4b438628e938) so that animating a statue this way produces a live flesh golem, and via [commit d8a0f734](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4) so that the same occurs for figurines.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Golem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golem "wikipedia:Golem")***

The *gōlem* is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The stone golem is a being that appears in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, debuting in the first *Monster Manual*. Stone golems are constructed from a single piece of carefully chiseled stone to serve as guardians, with the most elegant of stone golems doubling as art pieces - they are generally made with a bipedal and humanoid shape, stylized to suit their creator. The average stone golem is about 9 ft (2.7 m) tall and weighs approximately 2,000 lb (910,000 g). A stone golem always fights with its brute strength and fists and will dutifully obey whoever constructed it, being able to understand simple commands; this included falling into a dormant state to await and attack any other creatures that showed signs of hostility. Stone golems are immune to magic and resistant to un-enchanted weaponry, with the exception of spells designed to work against stone and earth - "stone to flesh" in particular temporarily weakened a stone golem, rendering it vulnerable to normal weapons.

## Messages

- \<The stone golem> is heating up!

  A stone golem was hit by a flaming attack.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), stone golems are always generated with 180 HP and are made vulnerable to [rays](/wiki/Ray "Ray") from the [dig](/wiki/Spellbook_of_dig "Spellbook of dig") spell and [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging"), which halves their HP (reducing it to a minimum of 1).[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), one of the special levels in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") included from the [Heck² patch](/wiki/Heck%C2%B2_patch "Heck² patch") generates three stone golems at level creation. A fifth stone golem is added to the monsters generated on that Plane of Earth at level creation, and another is added to the monsters generated on the Plane of Fire at level creation.

Sixteen statues of stone golems are placed around the locate level of the [Archeologist quest](/wiki/Archeologist_quest "Archeologist quest").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), stone golems always generate with 100 HP.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, a stone golem is generated asleep in the Boulder Bonanza map of [Mines' End](/wiki/Mines%27_End "Mines' End"), and two stone golems are generated in the [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room") closets within [Ruggo the Gnome King](/wiki/Ruggo_the_Gnome_King "Ruggo the Gnome King")'s [special level](/index.php?title=Special_level_\(SlashTHEM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Special level (SlashTHEM) (page does not exist)") at level creation. As in dNetHack and its variants, one of the special levels in Gehennom included from the Heck² patch generates three stone golems at level creation.

## Encyclopedia entry

Stone golems share the following [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") entry with other golems that lack their own entry:

"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth  
century. Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is  
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to  
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other  
menial work.  
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort  
of vegetable half-life. What life it had, too, so the story  
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its  
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the  
\`free sidereal strength of the universe.'  
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take  
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.  
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its  
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and  
destroyed it. Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless. All that was  
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in  
the Old Synagogue." ...

\[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]

A '''stone golem''', {{monsym|stone golem}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The stone golem is [[thick-skinned]], and is one of the stronger types of [[golem]].

A stone golem has a single claw attack, and possesses [[stoning resistance]] along with the [[sleep resistance]] and [[poison resistance]] of all golems.

A [[hero]] that is subjected to [[stoning]] while [[polymorph]]ed into any other golem will become a stone golem.{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|2212|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|2841|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Generation==
Randomly-generated stone golems are always created hostile. Stone golems are always generated with 60 [[HP]].{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1987|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Stone golems can generate as a result of [[polypiling]] if there are enough [[copper]], [[silver]], [[platinum]], [[gemstone]], or [[mineral]] objects in a pile of items.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|1306|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Stoning any other type of golem will turn them into a stone golem.{{refsrc|src/mon.c|2525|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

The second map for [[Medusa's Island]] generates four stone golems just outside of [[Medusa]]'s room at level creation.{{refsrc|dat/medusa.des|197|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Four stone golems are generated on the [[Plane of Earth]] at level creation, and two are generated on the [[Plane of Fire]] at level creation.

Stone golems leave behind a [[statue]] of themselves containing their inventory upon death [[Corpseless|instead of a corpse]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|395|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} They are not a valid target for [[genocide]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Per {{commit|a1b765936f807729e1c2cf3c7a9b928e34a277f5}}, stone golems generate with 100 HP.}}

==Strategy==
Stone golems have a fairly powerful attack and slightly more AC than most golems, but they move half as fast as an unburdened player and lack most resistances outside of the usual ones for golems, so they should not be too difficult to defeat.

Casting [[stone to flesh]] on a stone golem will turn it into a [[flesh golem]]: while this makes it faster and more resistant, as well as giving it more damaging attacks, the flesh golem also has worse AC and base HP. Heroes that encounter stone golems through normal generation are usually well-equipped to handle flesh golems, and can use the spell to try and gain certain [[intrinsic]]s from the corpses - this also applies to the statues that stone golems leave behind upon being 'destroyed'.

Remember that statues left over from killing stone golems will not contain any items like randomly generated statues, minus whatever inventory the stone golem already possessed (which only occurs if they were polymorphed from another monster); randomly-generated statues of stone golems in the dungeon may still contain [[spellbook]]s as normal.

==History==
The stone golem first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. 

From NetHack 3.0.0 to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including some variants based on those versions, a hero in stone golem form that casts stone to flesh at themselves while [[wielding]] a [[footrice]] corpse without [[gloves]] will become a [[flesh golem]] as expected, but will not be affected by the wielded corpse - this is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] via {{commit|b99f8a0ebb5f3ef958133b2b1a2f75a01726caf8}} so that the hero will immediately become a stone golem again in this case.

Additionally, casting stone to flesh at a statue or [[figurine]] of a stone golem produces a single [[meatball]], since any golem other than the flesh or [[leather golem]] is considered "[[vegetarian]]" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in NetHack 3.6.0 via {{commit|30d81e909793081790b0aa1d127c4b438628e938}} so that animating a statue this way produces a live flesh golem, and via {{commit|d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4}} so that the same occurs for figurines.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Golem}}
The ''gōlem'' is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The stone golem is a being that appears in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', debuting in the first ''Monster Manual''. Stone golems are constructed from a single piece of carefully chiseled stone to serve as guardians, with the most elegant of stone golems doubling as art pieces - they are generally made with a bipedal and humanoid shape, stylized to suit their creator. The average stone golem is about 9 ft (2.7 m) tall and weighs approximately 2,000 lb (910,000 g). A stone golem always fights with its brute strength and fists and will dutifully obey whoever constructed it, being able to understand simple commands; this included falling into a dormant state to await and attack any other creatures that showed signs of hostility. Stone golems are immune to magic and resistant to un-enchanted weaponry, with the exception of spells designed to work against stone and earth - "stone to flesh" in particular temporarily weakened a stone golem, rendering it vulnerable to normal weapons.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], stone golems are always generated with 180 HP and are made vulnerable to [[ray]]s from the {{+ of|dig}} spell and [[wand of digging]], which halves their HP (reducing it to a minimum of 1).{{refsrc|makemon.c|2253|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|mondata.h|206|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|dig.c|1293|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], one of the special levels in [[Gehennom]] included from the [[Heck² patch]] generates three stone golems at level creation. A fifth stone golem is added to the monsters generated on that Plane of Earth at level creation, and another is added to the monsters generated on the Plane of Fire at level creation.

Sixteen statues of stone golems are placed around the locate level of the [[Archeologist quest]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], stone golems always generate with 100 HP.

===SlashTHEM===
In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details, a stone golem is generated asleep in the Boulder Bonanza map of [[Mines' End]], and two stone golems are generated in the [[throne room]] closets within [[Ruggo the Gnome King]]'s [[Special level (SlashTHEM)|special level]] at level creation. As in dNetHack and its variants, one of the special levels in Gehennom included from the Heck² patch generates three stone golems at level creation.

==Encyclopedia entry==
Stone golems share the following [[encyclopedia]] entry with other golems that lack their own entry:
{{encyclopedia|
"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth
century.  Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other
menial work.
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort
of vegetable half-life.  What life it had, too, so the story
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the
`free sidereal strength of the universe.'
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and
destroyed it.  Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless.  All that was
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in
the Old Synagogue." ...
|[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]
